>Women of /adv/, why did you choose your boyfriend?
We met on the internet back in 2017. We were immediately drawn to each other from the first time we talked. We had natural chemistry and loved talking to one another. We're both very reserved people and yet it felt so natural to open up to each other. I wasn't doing very well and neither was him, and neither of us is the kind of person to open up with a stranger, but I felt safe with him, and him with me.
I knew we had something special.

From the first time we spent time together in person I knew I was going to marry him. Told my parents about it after one date. My stomach hurt from laughing, I felt completely at ease with him, conversation felt so effortless. I talked to him about things that I struggled to open up about with my lifelong friends.
Our relationship felt like a romance movie. I never felt so intensely about a man, I never felt so clearly loved and wanted. We never wanted to be apart from each other, every minute we spent together was filled with love and desire. I immediately felt like I found my person and I have never felt alone since.
Whether we are reading books to each other until we fall asleep, dancing in the kitchen, making love until we are too sore to get out of bed, staying up all night talking and laughing, hopping in the car because he woke up wanting to go see some cool place with me, or going to the bowling alley at the end of the street on a monday morning, I've felt incredibly blessed every single day of our relationship.

He's very kind, and really just has a child like purity to him - he's empathetic, genuine, loving. He wears his heart on his sleeve. He's always himself and isn't afraid to stand up for the things he believes in, but he's never a dick about it. There was never one time I thought he crossed the line or he acted poorly towards someone. He never raised his voice with me in 5 years we've been together, said anything mean to me during a disagreement.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28297393
How did I start figuring it out--female puberty was awful, for a start. Not in terms of getting unwanted attention or mood swings type of stuff, but it felt like my body was progressively deforming, like I was growing this unrecognizable woman-shaped fatsuit that I couldn't peel off, all over my body. I looked at male classmates later on and felt confused and envious. the stuff that was happening to them seemed like it would tolerable, or even desirable.

My dreams, my fantasies about the future and about sex, often had anything from complete genderswap to a lot of confusing gendered elements in them. for a while I was having dreams where people would walk up to me in a public place and loudly denounce me for being a boy in disguise. That feeling was also present in women's locker rooms.

My classmates bullied the shit out of me constantly for walking, talking, moving "like a man." I was trying very hard at that point to crush it down and do the socially appropriate femininity, but I could never figure it out. I looked like a guy doing a bit and people took care to rub it in.

I only felt comfortable online, back when being extremely online was barely a thing. All my profile pictures and online personas, video game personas, were guys. it was the only way I felt normal.

I also got constant "dyke" comments but being attracted almost exclusively to men it was easier for me than most to not get sidetracked thinking I was a butch lesbian. There was no excuse for me.

I'd still say I wasn't 100% sure until I started physical transition though. after a few weeks of male-range testosterone levels I was very sure.

anon holy shit. i had no idea someone else out there was going through what i'm going through. i am 21 years old, male, normal penis, normal everything else, but simply no testicles. i wasn't born with them. the doctors did all sorts of checks, confirmed i'm XY, just no testicles. it's called anorchia.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anorchia
i know it's not exactly the same as your situation but hopefully you can find some kinship in my story. i took an escalating dose of testosterone throughout puberty and now i'm steady at reandron 1000mg every 10 weeks. i'm curious to hear your dosage because maybe you need to see a different doctor to get more. a lower dose every two weeks was what i was on at 14.

i relate to the sex drive thing. i did once upon a time (in the first few years of treatment) but as an adult (since at least 17) i have felt nothing. no desire to pursue women outside of simply not wanting to be alone, but that to me is not powerful enough to put up with a lot of women so i simply don't have the drive. i did use porn back in those early days so I thought going nofap or noporn would help - i have tried both and in absence of that there's nothing. i don't masturbate at all anymore not because i'm nofap but because i simply have no desire to do so.
i take a lot of pills as well. particularly a lot of vitamins. i have tried all sorts of anti-depressants and none worked. wellbutrin did for a few weeks but eventually made me worse than not taking them did.

maybe you don't get this, but for me personally i have been struggling with small amounts of gender dysphoria. i have so many traits that are unattractive in men but attractive in women (far apart eyes, being short, etc.) that combined with how i was born, i sometimes can't help but feel whatever was going on with my parents genetics/how i developed in my mother's womb contradicted what god had ultimately intended for me.

>>28306345
I am positive that if you broke a promise you made to god, he wouldn’t destroy or hurt you over it.

The problem is that by breaking your own word, you lessen the value of your self-worth, and THAT is the real sin.

I don’t mean a sin unto God, I mean a sin against yourself. We are who we are, AND we are who we believe ourselves to be. If you make promises to yourself that you aren’t willing to keep, soon you will give up believing yourself because you know you can’t be trusted.

Here’s an ACTUAL advice. Don’t make promises. Just don’t do it. Promises should be sacred and rare, and used only in extreme situations.

Instead, make a comfortable contract with yourself that’s very lax and forgiving. Here’s one:
>”This is a contract I make with myself. My name is <anon>, and I hereby declare that I will try, as best I can, to try to give up vaping. I know it won’t be perfect, and I know I might vape again, but I need to remind myself as to never forget that my goal is to give it up for good. So even if I do vape, I will make a conscientious to try to give it up. It may take me a year, or two, but I will strive to always try my best to go as long as I can, as often as I can, without vaping. Also if I happen to fail and vape, I will read this contract, forgive myself, and try again until one day I quit vaping for good. <signed anon>

If you vaped every day for a year, and in the next year you only vaped every other day, that’s progress. Then once every three days. Once a week. Once a month. Etc.

As long as you always try, always make an effort, eventually your body will reward you with what you want and you will break free.

Good luck.

I know it is hard to believe, specially in our modern society where tits and abs are shown to us everywhere 24/7, but most women dont really care that much about appearance when it comes to their partners - they *really* prefer confidence and personality (unless we are talking about whores who want one night stands, but thats not a relationship).

Physical change is natural - every cell of your body is replaced every 10 years or so, but your soul remains untouched by time. If your soul is unattractive, you need to get rid of it to make room for a new one.
You are both the marble and the sculptor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28301021
>Is it really worth it long term though? Seems like short sighted gains for lifelong losses...
IMO, yes.
The addictive nature is more of a dependency than a true addiction, as someone who experiences both. You don't suffer withdrawals like shakes or anything, nor a craving for it. You "crash," both physically and mentally, but you bounce back after a good night or two of rest.
The health effects are scary, but still modest and ultimately won't hit until you are already in the last third of your life (50 to 75).
The main reasons not to take it:
>if you are under 22
it can stunt physical development and might have adverse effects on psychological development (with the latter element not really established in the literature)
>if you are prone to psychosis
>if you are exceptionally prone to heart disease
and I would be very cautious if you suffer from an addictive personality disorder, but I do (I think) and am fine with it - even as I've grown addictions to things like THC, nicotine, porn, and so on.

>>28300817
This is real life, and there's no such thing as cheating. Life is difficult, and it's a desperate scramble to accomplish something in the time we have. If something makes it easier, that's awesome. If there's a tradeoff, you've gotta weigh it for yourself (no one else can do it for you).

See Paul Erdos. Dude was one of the greatest and most prolific mathematicians of the 20th century. And he also spent the last 20 years of his life on amphetamines cranking out paper after paper. Was that cheating? What does that even mean in the context of genuinely moving field of mathematics forward. The fact is, he accomplished great things, it doesn't matter that he had some chemical assistance.

All that being said, I've never done amphetamines, so I can't really speak to that specifically. Just, overall, I don't like this idea that you can "cheat" at life. If it helps you, and as a result you can be a better person and contribute to society, that's all that matters.

Tldr take your damn meds and live a better life than now

As another married guy in your position OP, I can tell you the urge never goes away. In my case it's my wife who's regularly travelling. It's not even a lack of sex from her, but like others have said it's the innate drive to conquer someone new. I've grown considerably more attractive to women now I'm in my 30s and definitely get noticed more, whether it's due to increased financial stability or simply growing into my looks, it's been hard to ignore.

The more you do this, though, the more likely it is that you'll meet someone you want to be around more than your wife. Contempt lies that way. You may have all the logistics and opsec down to a T. But once you meet that perfect sexually compatible partner, perhaps even that person your wife once was, who does those torrid, incredible things for you your wife maybe once did, you will find yourself increasingly distracted. Your wife will notice this. You may tell yourself you're in control and that sex is just an act. I did. Despite this, it only has to happen once to send your marriage into a tailspin of suspicion and distrust. Going down this path, you can't put toothpaste back in the tube.

Disregard the moral and Christfaggotry in this thread. Pay closer attention to those pointing to what you want out of your life in the long term. I haven't stepped out of my marriage for a while now. I have contemplated divorce many times. There will come a time, and that time is closer than many of us think, when we're old and our looks have faded for good. We will look back at all this, perhaps with shame, perhaps married, perhaps single. We will no doubt judge ourselves by the choices we make right now. Do you care about that at all? Do you -actually- want to remain monogamous?

I can't say I've decided on these things myself, yet. Or that I really care about my social standing, or what others may think of what I do. My wife is a good person, unlike some. But the call of the wild is loud.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been there, bro.

Recognize that you only want to die because you feel your obstacles are insurmountable. But you have hands, eyes, feet, and a brain. You can do a lot of shit in life. Starting with the idea that you're incapable or unlovable is like slashing your tires before you start driving. I believe in you. Even when getting out of bed is a challenge, remember that I believe in you. And why? Because you have everything you need to be successful in you already. So keep your tires inflated, and drive to that destination. Whether it takes a day or a lifetime, your life depends on it.

I'm an artist and it's unbelievably hard to motivate myself, but if I can make one funny little drawing, I've made that day worthwhile. Take a small step for yourself in any way you please. Not because it will fix your life but because it's what you can do.

Living is always going to be harder than being dead, which is what we spend almost all of our existence doing. I think this moment is worth trying for.

>>28294470

I was a NEET from late teens into early 20s. Worked off and on trying to sort myself out but fell to depression and anxiety as my peers seemed to have the next step (uni, kids, whatever) all fall into place for them.

At 22 I'd finally end up in college and almost drop out before graduating with a 3.2 GPA in a renowned tough program.

For my mid 20's to early 30s, I worked white collar for a few years and would NEET inbetween.

At first I would study, achieve my goal and then be aimless towards the end of my time, falling back into video games and degeneracy. Eventually that would get boring and I got better about staying somewhat productive. (Exercise and an hour a day of proper learning at a minimum.)

At the beginning of covid I got a new job and was forced into a role where I had to be social and interact with people fairly often. I'm not the most social irl. One on one and in small groups I can manage. Quiet but people seem to like me somehow.

There's not really an easy way to come back from being a NEET without going through some uncomfortable moments.

Covid is a great excuse for your employment history and social atrophy but you still have to practice every opportunity you get.

This year I'm on the verge of moving out for the first time at 30. Not sure how I managed when I didn't even think I'd live to see this age, but here we are.

posts.com: I don’t have a lot of self confidence and feel like I live life as an observer rather than the main character. I’ve done stuff like travel to foreign countries, had jobs (but standard wagie type ones), etc. My experience with being around other people is that you get ignored unless you are noticeably unique, and I mean actually have a personality. If you’re quiet all the time people ignore you or even pretend you like don’t exist. So I want to break out of this, where should I start? For context I’m 26 and living in the US. I understand there is something seriously wrong with me to be virgin and friendless at this age.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>28306493

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28306493

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28306493
I was in a similar situation. Went to high school and college, and felt like I had never really made a single decision in my life. Like I hadn't really been conscious or aware of my place in the world.

The thing that helped me the most, honestly, was just living alone for like 6+ years. It's amazing how much you learn about yourself when you limit external constraints on your behavior.

When you're living alone, you're free to be really fucking weird in a safe space. Want to spend the weekend naked in the apartment playing video games and talking to yourself like a madman? Want to tape some paper to the walls, get hammered, and try to make something creative? Want to go to a local craft fair or some weird shit?

The world is is your oyster, because you've got a space of your own to experiment in. To trust try what works for you without the fear of being judged.

I'd also recommend writing. Journaling, taking notes, whatever. It's helpful to take thoughts out of your mind and make them concrete. The inside of your mind... is a weird place, and it distorts things. It's really good at convincing you you understand something, when you just really fucking don't.

Just start writing a journal entry once a day, it's a perfect place to build a personality.

posts.sub: How to deal with sensitive hearing
posts.com:
I have extremely sensitive hearing because of my autism. I hear tiny bass frequencies in my apartment complex and they drive me fucking insane. They just don't end and it's become all I can focus on and it's taken a serious toll on my mental health and made me more irritable and irrational. I want to dull my senses somehow so that I don't have to deal with it.
Any suggestions? Medication, therapy, surgery? Earplugs don't work, the bass permeates beyond that. Noise cancelling headphones do work but I don't want to have to wear them 24/7 just to be sane. Should I see an OT?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28303984

I’m sort of like you and I always wanted to build an isolation box to solve this problem.

The only way to block low frequencies is to simply have more mass between you and the source to absorb the vibration. So I was thinking of building a wooden box lined with something heavy that you can seal yourself in. You’d have to have ventilation and the lining would have to be of sufficient mass to stop vibrations from your floor. Or maybe you could put some shock absorbing material between the box and the floor.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: You could definitely put up material on your walls to help with this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28303984
I had to live through a nightmare where my upstairs neighbor would non-stop have music playing or a loud ass fan running I literally had a mental breakdown at one point because of it.

Blocking low frequency noise is basically impossible, it requires very dense material I ened up just buying a high quality set of noise cancelling headphones and I wore them basically 24/7. The best solution is to just move to someplace where you are less likely to be bothered but of course that isn't always realistic.

>>28304657
Noise foam and other materials stop sound from bouncing around inside your room, it may stop some high frequency noises, but it is useless against low frequency noise. Noise foam is basically to stop echos you make, it doesn't block outside noise from coming in.

I have a pretty large Russian Blue cat. He's muscular and powerful, 28lbs (which is fucking huge for a cat) and a very avid predator whenever I let him out for the few hours I let him out a day.
(I live in an area with no natural predators for him.)
Recently I was doing some home improvement and was replacing rotten wood covering the crawl space under the house when I discovered my cats "stash".
Literally 30-40 dead animal carcasses of his kills.
There was fish, birds, mice, squirrels, puppies, a ferret looking type of animal, and some snakes.
All were half eaten or mostly eaten and there was some skeletons as well.

After seeing and smelling it I've been throwing up constantly for like 4 days now and can't eat.
Before this I considered myself pretty immune to this type of stuff, but it's like against my will how much it's grossing my body out for whatever reason.
Like in my mind I don't find it gross, but my body subconsciously does or something and makes itself sick.
It's also the fact that half of the kills were fish from the creek that goes through my property, and the fish has a very unique rotting smell compared to the other animals, and both odors mixed together really fucked me up.

What the fuck can I do? I'm dehydrated at this point but I can't hardly even keep water down without puking.
This is literally 4 days later and it's still the same.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>letting your cat outside
>no natural predators
Cats hunt, but if they eat at home, they don't know what to do with their catch. Also, humans kill cats, it may be only a small portion of folk, but things like cars, pellet guns, et cetera are used to purposely kill cats. Not to mention diseases, and hawks. In general, it isn't a good idea to let your cat outside unattended.

>what do I do
Call animal control, and have them remove the carcasses. Make sure to drink and eat things to refill your electrolytes after so much puking; I reccomend Pedilyte. The smell should go away after body removal, but if it doesn't, look into stuff like enzymatic cleaners. Btw, your cat probably hides under there, and the rotting flesh poses a health risk to him, too.

Wait until you start having headaches from exposure to toxoplasmosis, which is a parasite your cat undoubtedly catches in the wild, and then, via feces, contaminates you.

Toxoplasmosis forces the cat to be amiable to the owner so if your cat has shown affection, now you know why. Especially at night when cats will usually wait until the owner is asleep and then position their anuses in proximity to your mouth. At that point a little larva reacts to Co2 (which is expelled via our breath when we exhale) and makes its way into your mouth.

Let’s just hope toxoplasmosis doesn’t get stuck in your brain. There’s no cure when that happens and it’s downright nasty. And deadly.

>>28306041
I never encountered that other ballet fan again, so I'll never know if she ended up watching it or not. I could watch more ballet recommended by you, but those last two you recommended for MacMillan seemed to have only low-quality recordings on YouTube. It would have to be something more popular to have good videos available, I think.

The show I recommended to her was Legend of the Galactic Heroes. It's a corny title, but the name refers to the distinction between legends (pre-history) and history (post-legends). It's about an interstellar war that's similar to Star Wars, between a Galactic Empire and a Rebel Alliance, but the story is told from both points of view, with neither side being the "good guys" and neither side being the "bad guys".

Oh, and the soundtrack is all classical music.

It's about a war, but the fighting isn't the true focus. Fans of this series love it for the character work and drama. Here's a beloved scene.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m0g--JT7K7Y

Battles aren't exciting, and the music even gives them grace and beauty as you ponder the tragic loss of life in this cosmic ballet.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ry4OnhxDGoI

There's a helpful narrator who explains many details, and there are times when it's more like a documentary than a traditional narrative.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Yauioxzb0fw


Top Three Anime:
Legend of the Galactic Heroes (110 episodes, but you can know whether or not you'll like it after the first 7 or so)
Rose of Versailles (40 episodes about a French noblewoman whose father raised her to be a nobleMAN leading up to the French Revolution)
The Tatami Galaxy (11 episodes about learning to not feel too much regret over how you spent your time in school)

posts.com:
When I met my gf I was in a bad mental state from the end of a 3.5 year relationship that ended suddenly without any fight, argument, accident, or discernable reason about 8 months prior. According my ex's sister, she just didn't want to date anymore, moved in with their parents from her own place, and has remained single ever since.

No rape or any other abuse has ever happened to her. I took care of every need and want she had other than her rent and car stuff, and her entire family accepted me as one of them.

She was happy, grateful for everything, and we were even talking about getting married a week before. To this day only she knows why, but her actions messed with my head.

My current gf helped me get back to functional over 1.5 years, then she escalated us to dating. After a couple years together something changed in the way I saw her but I didn't know what. Almost like exclusive friends with benefits rather than bf/gf feelings of past relationships. She has never felt that way about me.

Now it's been another year of feeling like this, and after much thought I realized that we had done the last of the things I'd wanted to do with my ex around the same time things changed for me. I think I was subconsciously using my gf as some sort of substitute to get closure even though they don't have much in common, and now that it's done I'm not sure how I feel about the woman who is absolutely in love with me.

She's not really my type physically and has zero plans or ambitions in life other than make just enough money for food, shelter, and bills. We get along well and do have a fair amount in common, but we also disagree on some major talking points and have no real goal to work towards as a couple.

I don't necessarily want to break up with her. She's easily the kindest, sweetest, and most thoughtful person I've met. There's definitely potential chemistry here. I'm just restarting a relationship roughly 4 years into it and I'm not sure if I like it.

Because you're incompetent at managing your emotions so you solve that by not having them.
Might be time to change. Practice HAVING the emotion, but not using it or agreeing with it until you've checked that your emotion matches reality (i.e. don't stay attracted to people who don't like you).

Yes if you're a schizo who hallucinates that all your emotions are real, you'll make dumb decisions when the emotions tell you to.
But you're not a schizo, are you? You can tell when an emotion should be stopped instead of repeated. So take the irritation of having emotions you don't need, to reap the benefits of ones you do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Parking is the biggest hassle. You could consider a monthly pass for a parking garage. If you see the contract and theres nothing about sleeping in the car (there probably will be an explicit clause about no living in car allowed, but you never know) then give it a shot. Could be $100-200 per month in an average city

Anyway, downtown in most cities has 100 different no parking signs. "Zoned for music unloading / loading between 8-11pm" or "15 minute vendor pickup/delivery" or whatever. Its so easy to get towed in a downtown area. Then you try and go 15 minutes drive in any direction away from downtown and you have suburban streets. But those people will call the police. I'm not sure what police can actually do depending on jurisdiction but you said florida basically bans it, yeah? In california cops cant do shit about people parking in front of wealthy homes and living in their vans for years. Anyway, past the suburbs are grassy areas but its always fenced off or otherwise inaccessible. City parks have curfews on parking and tow trucks always drive through.
